poll_list.title: Ratification Poll for Add Data Insights Core Unit Budget (MIP40c3-SP64) - April 11, 2022

discourse_list.title: MIP40c3-SP64: Add Data Insights Core Unit Budget

content.content: MIP40c3-SP64: Add Data Insights Core Unit Budget  Preamble MIP40c3-SP#: 64 Author(s): Tomek Mierzwa (@tmierzwa), Tadeo (@tadeo), Piotr (@piotr.kils) Contributors: Tags: core-unit, cu-din-001, budget, dai-budget, mkr-budget, active Status: Accepted Date Applied: 2022-03-09 Date Ratified:  2022-04-25 Forum URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip40c3-sp64-add-data-insights-core-unit-budget/13791 Ratification Poll URL: https://vote.makerdao.com/polling/Qme3VaY4   Sentence Summary This subproposal adds the budget for Data Insights Core Unit. It’s a regular monthly budget of 90,250.00 DAI from May 2022 until April 2023, included.  Paragraph Summary MIP40c3-SP64 adds the budget for Data Insights Core Unit (DIN-001) to account for the new mandate that expands on the initial mission to maintain the existing data assets and build new datasets to cover L2s, RWAs, and puts a special focus on the community. The main changes are the following:  59,500 DAI → 90,250.00 DAI per month (+52%) 6 month budget → 12 month budget Team headcount increase Expansion Pool MKR vesting program Travel budget   Specification  Motivation We are proposing this budget for the Data Insights Core Unit to be able to continue our mission to provide free and permissionless datasets with contextualized and enriched MCD Protocol data and to continuously support and empower other members of the DAO and Community in the field of data analytics and data science. The previous mandate was defined as a kind of Proof of Concept to validate the need of a data focused Core Unit. It was mostly limited to supporting other Core Units by maintaining and updating the existing assets. The new mandate expands on the initial mission to build completely new datasets to cover L2s, RWAs, and puts a special focus on the community. This budget represents a 52% increase (59,500.00 DAI to 90,250.00 DAI per month) from the previous budget. The Data Insights Core Unit currently consists of three full-time members and one part-time facilitator. We have just hired one full-time member and we are planning to increase our workforce by an additional 1-2 contributors in the near future.  Core Unit ID DIN-001  Current status Having completed four out of the six months of the initial proposal, we believe we have demonstrated the value of this Core Unit to the protocol, to other Core Units ,as well as to the wider community. In the following post you can find an in-depth overview of the work done and the associated financials: link here. We would like to highlight the following aspects:   We constantly develop and maintain analytical datasets and GUIs covering many aspects of the protocol’s history (vaults, users, voting, liquidations, debt/surplus auctions, system parameters, etc.)   We regularly engage with other Core Units, providing them with various services: from Data API (for analysis and as backends for their applications) to reports, analyses and visualisations:  Risk CU GovAlpha CU Growth CU Strategic Finance CU    We continuously engage with partners (such as Oazo/oasis.app) and community members.   We have been fiscally responsible by:  Creating our own contingency buffer by reducing the team salaries in order to maintain operations if the current proposal is delayed or to gracefully wind down the Core Unit in case of rejection/offboarding. Optimizing costs, making it possible to return excess of funds to the protocol (currently estimated at 12% of total initial budget). Not incorporating a dedicated company and therefore being able to return the excess funds of 10,000 DAI originally allocated as the Incorporation Budget.     Roadmap The roadmap proposed below is a natural continuation to our current roadmap. We want to highlight the importance that L2s and RWAs will have in our future.  2332×474 50.9 KB  We plan to adhere to the upcoming SES Ecosystem Performance initiative, making our work more accessible to delegates and the community. In addition, we are looking into new tools that would allow the community to engage and provide direct feedback.  Budget Breakdown The budget has been designed re-using mechanisms implemented by other Core Units to enable greater transparency and standardisation throughout the DAO. We deeply appreciate their work, in particular that of SES.  Dai Expenditure We are asking for a Annual Budget Cap of 1,083,000.00 DAI. The cap refers to the maximum that the Core Unit can request for operating and it includes room for unforeseen circumstances. The distribution of budget across these components is shown below:     Cost component Amount     Team costs DAI 39,500.00   - Current Team DAI 39,500.00   Data costs DAI 17,500.00   - Decoded source data costs DAI 17,500.00   Infrastructure costs DAI 3,100.00   - AWS infrastructure DAI 1,000.00   - Snowflake subscription DAI 2,000.00   - Other subscriptions DAI 100.00   Operational costs DAI 5,150.00   - Finance, admin DAI 3,500.00   - Travel DAI 1,650.00   Expansion Pool DAI 25,000.00    The total monthly budget asked for is DAI 90,250.00 for the 12 months period from May 2022 until April 2023, included.  Expansion Pool We want to be fully transparent but also very flexible to meet the future demands of the protocol. With that in mind, we want to request a dedicated pool of funds that will be used for a variety of purposes, all of them with the goal of increasing the value delivered to the protocol. These uses include hiring new team members, funding grants to community members, engaging in partnerships and using new tools and services. Our thinking in requesting such a pool of funds is that we want to avoid misappropriating allocated funds while acknowledging that our current plans can change in the future in the the best interest of the protocol. To exemplify the above: the previous budget allocated funds for a part-time front-end developer. We ultimately realised it was not the best use of our resources given that we could maximise our impact by collaborating and empowering other Core Units building front-ends. We recently hired a new team member that has a wide range of skills but can be mostly categorised as back-end. This could be considered a misappropriation of funds so we hope our intentions are not misconstrued by the community. Another example of this is the use of additional services. While we currently host all of our data pipelines ourselves, we are considering using a managed service that would reduce our workload, allowing us to shift our focus from maintaining datasets to building new ones.  Contingency The Expansion Pool also includes the contingency buffer of ~3% of the total budget to cover infrastructure related unexpected expenses, but could potentially help us in case of miscalculations in other budget items such as Operational Costs. We are discussing a potential implementation of a new tooling to make data more accessible, particularly Redash. This will allow more users to make use of our datasets, given that we pay per use, if the tool is successful in attracting more users than expected, this will ultimately increase the cost of both hosting and database costs. We will publish our financials on a quarterly basis, attributing the ultimate use of those funds to the appropriate budget item.  MKR Vesting We propose a MKR Vesting program in line with the one set out by the SES Core Unit.  Estimated MKR Expenditure The Estimated MKR Expenditure is our best guess of how much MKR will be used with the current team configuration. Reasons why the Actual MKR Expenditure could rise closer to the MKR Expenditure Cap:  A raise for a member of the team New hires (two are covered by the cap) Repricing (and resetting) the program, in the case of bear market   MKR Amount Forecast For the permanent team, assuming the team configuration remains the same as today, this would result in the vesting schedule below.     Vesting Date MKR Amount     31 May 2023 110.16 MKR   30 Nov 2023 55.08 MKR   31 May 2024 55.08 MKR   30 Nov 2024 55.08 MKR   31 May 2025 55.08 MKR   Total 330.48 MKR    This covers the total vesting schedule of 3 years for the current 3.25 FTEs. Any changes to these amounts and its disbursement will be reported in the quarterly financials.  Vesting Parameters     Property Value     MKR/USD lock-in Method Trailing 6 month average   MKR/USD lock-in Price USD 2,428.74   MKR Price Floor -30%   Vesting Period 3 years   Cliff Vest 12 months   Vesting Schedule After cliff has expired, the MKR amount vests every 6 months   Manual Repricing yes   Auto-Renewal yes     Total MKR Expenditure Cap The total MKR Expenditure will not exceed 925.50 MKR. This covers the maximum of a 3 year plan for 5.25 FTEs.  Budget implementation  Core Unit wallet This budget implementation is a “Simple Budget Implementation” under MIP40c4.  Core Unit wallet address: 0x7327Aed0Ddf75391098e8753512D8aEc8D740a1F  Keyholders:   @tmierzwa - 0x5Fc4d6cF7777FF7A89268562959680dF6e6DD83D   @piotr.klis - 0xc6Ffa10CeFE1dA15f6Bc66428B1e73758D284394   @tadeo - 0x89E14956C6fBB814B281B0A1598E11297713c6d0     We are currently investigating the best way to implement additional wallet security measures like external multisig owners or an Auditor multisig.  Transfers  unused Incorporation Budget (10,000.00 DAI) and other unused funds from existing monthly budget (est. 45,000.00 DAI) will be returned to the protocol not later than on 2022-05-10 the total of 1,083,000.00 DAI will be streamed to 0x7327Aed0Ddf75391098e8753512D8aEc8D740a1F starting 2022-05-01 and ending 2023-04-30 at a rate of 90,250.00 DAI per month
content.GPT-summary: The post is a proposal to add a budget for the Data Insights Core Unit. The proposal expands on the initial mission to maintain existing data assets and build new datasets to cover L2s, RWAs, and puts a special focus on the community. The post explains the motivation, current status, roadmap, budget breakdown, and implementation of the proposal. The post also includes positive feedback, constructive criticism, and an extension to the proposal.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal
3rd party or author wants to collaborate on proposal

content.content: I am going to be asking this question of all CUs because unless revenues increase expense ramps in CUs of 50% within less than a year of inception at some point are going to have to be questioned and likely put on hold. Rather than focus on ‘expansion’ can you elaborate on what the minimum expenses this CU could function with and explain in detail the requirement for a 49% increase.   What does Maker lose if you don’t get your 49% expansion. You also write:     tmierzwa:  To exemplify the above - the previous budget allocated funds for a part-time front-end developer that we ultimately realised was not the best use of our resources given that we could maximise our impact by collaborating and empowering other core units building front-ends. We recently hired a new team member that has a wide range of skills but can be mostly categorised as back-end. This could be considered a misappropriation of funds so we hope our intentions are not misconstrued by the community.   This is the kind of initial waste I expect in bringing up new CUs that would lead to a later reduction in budgetary needs.   Perhaps better co-ordination with other units like DUX etc. that would be better suited (and could be specifically tasked with making front ends for data) would be beneficial from a cost perspective.     tmierzwa:  Another example of this is the use of additional services. While we currently host of our data pipelines ourselves, we are considering using a managed service that would reduce our workload, allowing us to shift our focus from maintaining datasets to building new ones.   The above ‘should’ be going towards reducing expenses because less resources (most certainly TechOps btw) should be required.  The idea of expanding is great in theory but the funds have to come from somewhere, and be sustainable and the organization to make effective decisions on budgets has to know what we don’t gain or what we might lose if the budget is NOT expanded (or worse contracted).   Regarding 24/7/365 TechOps part of your budget, would the services needed here be suitable for the TechOps CU unit generally?   Point here is that if 24/7/365 TechOps is needed for each CU to do this effectively 1 man deep requires 6 FTEs (to include 24/7/365 coverage, sick, vacation, etc.) So the last question here is what is the minimum budget this team could work with and still produce the basic services that are absolutely needed that without would break basic MakerDAO services somewhere. Thank you!

content.content: Hi, @MakerMan  thanks for your feedback.     MakerMan:  What does Maker lose if you don’t get your 49% expansion.   In such case DICU would need to focus on maintaining existing assets and will not be able to keep up with the demand for new data domains, particularly L2s, which are particularly time sensitive. We also think it would not be possible to support the RWA efforts of onboarding external data into the DAO. This requires a lot of up-front dedication before being able to provide a tangible service/tooling/framework for the community. We would expect other CUs dedicating their own resources to this and therefore generating more inefficiencies throughout the DAO.     MakerMan:  This is the kind of initial waste I expect in bringing up new CUs that would lead to a later reduction in budgetary needs. Perhaps better co-ordination with other units like DUX etc. that would be better suited (and could be specifically tasked with making front ends for data) would be beneficial from a cost perspective.   We believe that collaborating with other CUs is very valuable, including, but not limited to, from an impact / cost perspective.The counterpoint is the need for some redundancy, given our decentralised model. In line with that, we still find value in creating our own data frontends using existing resources within the team. This is particularly useful when showcasing new datasets and making them more widely accessible. A recent example of this is the Protocol Parameters dataset, now accessible through the Governance Tracker.     MakerMan:  The above ‘should’ be going towards reducing expenses because less resources (most certainly TechOps btw) should be required. The idea of expanding is great in theory but the funds have to come from somewhere, and be sustainable and the organization to make effective decisions on budgets has to know what we don’t gain or what we might lose if the budget is NOT expanded (or worse contracted).   We agree, the above example would help use improve the  expense to output ratio. The main reason to have the Expansion pool instead of keeping the separate budget items is to be able to make cost effective decisions moving forward.     MakerMan:  Regarding 24/7/365 TechOps part of your budget, would the services needed here be suitable for the TechOps CU unit generally? Point here is that if 24/7/365 TechOps is needed for each CU to do this effectively 1 man deep requires 6 FTEs (to include 24/7/365 coverage, sick, vacation, etc.)   We wouldn’t expect so. The current challenges are related to ETL workflows orchestration (which is quite domain specific), not service maintenance. This is similar to the benefits of using the cloud managed Snowflake instead a self-hosted PostgreSQL database. The wording in the post was misleading, apologies.     MakerMan:  So the last question here is what is the minimum budget this team could work with and still produce the basic services that are absolutely needed that without would break basic MakerDAO services somewhere.   The minimum budget that would allow to maintain (not build) would be the continuation of the original one (0% increase). But we would not be able to generate a contingency/continuation buffer as we did before, so we would need to request the additional funds to cover any potential usage spikes in our infrastructure (AWS, Snowflake) and to gracefully unwind the CU in the case of an offboarding or an emergency shutdown. However, as the protocol continues to evolve, we expect the number of data requests to increase accordingly. If we do not meet these requirements, other CUs will have to deal with it, which will ultimately lead to higher costs.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal
3rd party or author wants to collaborate on proposal

We are in contact with SES to understand the implementation details, as well as other alternatives such as including external owners in our CUs multisig, similar to what is already implemented.

content.content: tmierzwa:  The minimum budget that would allow to maintain (not build) would be the continuation of the original one (0% increase).   what this cannot be real u say if governance doesnt increase budget u stop building and just maintain? after only 4 months of operations? pls say this cant be correct and this is not    MIP40c3-SP63: Modify Core Unit Budget, COM-001   If the DAO rejects the expansion, what does that mean for your budget? The problem with the way this is proposed, there is no opportunity to reject the expanded PR budget without defunding your CU, all-or nothing, if I understand correctly. From a game theoretic perspective this is coercion. In general, a CU mandate refresh and budget expansions should probably be presented independent of a budget supporting ongoing operations.

content.content: Hi @Deimos,     Deimos:  what this cannot be real u say if governance doesnt increase budget u stop building and just maintain? after only 4 months of operations? pls say this cant be correct and this is not   This statement was a gross simplification, sorry for this. We will be building new products, but maintenance of existing assets constantly increases with any new addition and takes more and more time. It is not just about the technical level. When we start working on any new initiative, we are committed to supporting it in the long term, which means making periodic improvements and modifications while coordinating with stakeholders. We also constanlty respond to ad-hoc requests, such as the Flapper Keeper dataset & visualisation to support a signal request discussion. Additionally, we acknowledge that reporting requirements of the DAO evolve in time. This will also increase our workload. Another lesson from the past period is that communicating what we have built is crucial and we must not assume that everyone is reading our forum posts or visiting our website. We know we need to dedicate more time to this.

content.content: Hi @Deimos , First of all, thank for taking the time to watch our call, irregardless of whether you disagree with us, we value that you are investing time and effort for the betterment of the community.     Deimos:  srsly we need to stop the foot in the door core unit little budget you have nothing to loose than ask for more even before proving value classic consulting trojan horse hidden cost   Careful experimentation in the DAO is important for growth, we believe we took the appropriate path to minimise the risks to the protocol while providing value along the way. The approved budget of November 2021 had the intention to serve as a “test run” to validate the possible value that a data-specific core unit could bring to the protocol. We propose this updated budget having had this past experience and making the best estimation of what needs the protocol will encounter in the coming year. This process is not perfect but we hope you understand the ultimate goal here.     Deimos:  in the call even admit they want to expand to rwf and they have no clue how to execute or scan pdf   We hope our openness is not confused with ignorance. We know the challenges of working with data in a financial institution environment (some of our members have previously worked with such institutions). We have discussed several ways we can contribute to the RWA initiatives, both within the team and with the different stakeholders inside and outside the DAO, because we don’t believe in doing things in isolation.     Deimos:  layer2 maker is not in layer2   We believe it is important to gain visibility into other chains as soon as possible to help us to better plan and measure key metrics. We are involved in the L2 Stakeholder Alignment initiative to be able to respond accordingly to those needs.

content.content: After being contacted by one of the @Recognized-Delegates about our collaborations with DIN-001, GovAlpha decided to draft this post. We believe that information available to the Recognized Delegates must also be available to the general community so voters may make fully informed decisions. This post is intended to detail how we currently utilize data from DIN-001 and how we might adapt if their budget proposal was not funded. We lean on DIN-001 primarily in the following ways:  Recognized Delegate Maintenance (Metrics tracking and Compensation varribles) Building on-chain effects into the voting portal (via DUX-001) Data API for our Governance Health Dashboard  Catflip Successor UI (in development from dSpot) Ranked Choice Voting Analysis (in progress, thanks to @tadeo )  We believe in building resilient systems, and thanks to our technical hire, @hernandoagf, we are confident we could either buy the data we are using and feed that into our processes or recreate some of the APIs ourselves. With that said, it would represent an increase in spending and labor for GovAlpha if the APIs we are currently getting from DIN-001 were to disappear. While all of the DAO sourcing their data from DIN-001 would represent a centralization risk, it is also worth noting that external providers will likely be more expensive and less responsive to the changing desires of the community. GovAlpha does not have an opinion on this particular budget proposal and has provided these points of consideration in the interests of transparency for the community. We are happy to answer any questions about what data is used for the projects mentioned above, as well as any questions pertaining to our collaboration.

content.content: Please note that we have included a travel item to the budget. We believe it’s important for a remote team to meet each other to develop interpersonal relationships. This includes meeting other CU members, delegates and the community at large by attending conferences. Important reminder that this proposal will enter its Frozen Period this week, on Thursday March 31st. The last day for modifications will be Wednesday March 30th. Please keep in mind that we will not be able to make major modifications to our budget before the vote in April.

content.content: On behalf of the DICU team I’m formally submitting this proposal. Best regards Tomek

Any modern business has data insight needs. The Data Insights Core unit (DIN-001) has demonstrated foresightedness and restraint in its use of the current budget allocated here. This is demonstrated by their willingness to return 10,000 DAI of the incorporation budget and another approximately 45,000 DAI of unused monthly budget. It is quite natural for data insight needs to grow when they are fulfilled timely and with consistent quality. DIN-001 wants to tackle additional data insight challenges arising from Layer two integrations and from RWA collateralization. This initiative can only be applauded. Three questions come to mind:  Is DIN-001 the appropriate place for layer-two data insights, or should that be provided by another core unit? Is DIN-001 the appropriate place for RWA data insights, or should that be provided by the respective core unit? Have alternative avenues of sourcing these insights been sufficiently explored?  From a business perspective, it makes sense to centralize data insights and analytics in a single core unit and not have each unit with insight demands maintain its own set of data and analysts. This provides synergies and ultimately cost savings. Nevertheless, the same is true vice-versa. It does not make sense for DIN-001 to develop, e.g. RWA data, when it is already developed elsewhere as a necessary part of that operation. This is why, while I support the notion of increasing the data insight CU’s budget, I want to make sure not to support mission creep. I want to see the most cost-effective solution to data insight needs, and I’m confident that DIN-001 have thought in depth about why they are the best place for L2 and RWA data insights and hope they can clarify that in response.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party extending to proposal

content.content: Hi @rspa, Thanks for your feedback! We tend to follow a use-case driven approach to building. This is highly dependent on collaboration as we mainly source use-cases from other CUs. What exactly we end up building depends a lot with whom we are collaborating with; in some cases it’s a more performant data feed and in others an analysis on voting behaviour.  Multiple CUs need to look at very similar L2 metrics, such as amount of non-canonical DAI in the chain, volume of other stable coins, amount transacted with each at different timescales, etc. We can then work with each CU to further tailor to their particular needs. RWAs involve multiple parties, including multiple CUs. We are working with several parties to first understand what information/data can be shared to help set-up a workflow to provide the data to the wider community. We are constantly trying to find better ways to support the DAO and the community. We collaborate with many CUs because they see more value in our services than doing it themselves or with another entity. We also aim at creating tools rather than products so CUs and other community members can work independently.

content.content: I’m going to expand on the above based on feedback I’ve received:  RWA TradFi data is a highly guarded asset, a highly regulated environment that has legal and technical challenges. Additionally, TradFi has a tendency for single ad-hoc implementations of systems and the reliance on emailed documentation. All these factors attest against the effective scaling of Maker’s RWA initiatives. Members of our team have previously worked with financial institutions and have the expertise to execute efficiently within this environment. We aim to build a framework and tools to empower our colleagues in RWF, LOVE and our partners, namely RWA Co & 6S Capital, to execute their mandates effectively by making RWA data as available as we’ve made on-chain data. A framework that will make it easy to replicate our efforts with every new deal and tools aimed at helping community members interact with RWA without having DICU as its gatekeeper.  L2s The advent of L2s means that there are now more than one data source. Each chain has its own specificities that will be translated into different deployments of the core infrastructure of Maker. This is a global effort that involves not only technical Core Units. We see our role as a critical support for the multiple core units. We want to create unified datasets to abstract away the complexities and make it fully accessible to everyone in the community. With every chain, there’s a replication effort of data feeds as well as an increased need to maintain changes in the different chains and exposing the cross-chain interactions. This is a time sensitive initiative, the collaborating core units need data insights to inform their decisions so we are focusing on how to be quick at responding to needs and proactively laying the groundwork for it.  Other areas While we highlighted RWA and L2s, we see other domains within Maker where we believe we can provide value in the next year. Governance has become an incredibly time consuming activity, discussions in the forum are often not supported with the right data. To effectively scale the DAO we all need to focus on data-driven decision making.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party extending to proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: Hi @flipflopflapdelegate , Data Insights Core Unit is not involved in any projects with StarkWare. At the same time Token Flow is the independent provider of the on-chain source data we use for building all Maker-related datasets. Token Flow is also a partner of StarkWare, actively involved in the StarkNet development and also provides (or plans to provide in a near future) data from other chains (zkSync, Optimism, Polygon, testnets, etc.). Having access to a wide range of reliable on-chain data is critical to our L2 strategy. Best regards Tomek

content.content: tmierzwa:  Token Flow is also a partner of StarkWare, actively involved in the StarkNet development   And if StarkNet was to go moon    (humor me  ) – how easily, or difficult will it be for the average community/Core Unit member to create datasets from this particular L2? Will the “average community/core unit member” need to be proficient in Cairo? Do you believe L2s will be a specialty niche for folks like DI CU?
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party extending to proposal

content.content: @flipflopflapdelegate, the answer is yes and no  Yes - because this data is fully permissionless, has similar structure as Ethereum (plus additionally cross-chain messaging) and using it does not require any specific knowledge about Cairo / rollups / etc. No - because it is still quite raw and technical (exactly like Ethereum data) and needs a lot of integration, semantic processing and enrichment. This is exactly what DICU does for L1 MCD data, transforming it from transactions / events / storage diffs into vault operations / governance actions / auction bids / protocol parameters changes. Only such data is easy to comprehend and use for an average user. We absolutely plan to deliver such datasets for L2 using the tools and knowledge we gathered working with L1 data. Of course if he have budget and resources to do this, as defined in our newest MIP submission which is being voted by delegates right now.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: I’m a little confused as to whether this team’s mission is more to support other core units or service the general public.  I suppose it could be both.  With the understanding that usage may not correlate to total value provided, would you be able to share your AWS and snowflake usage statistics and expenses? I’m also wondering about the maintenance costs of existing assets.     tmierzwa:  We will be building new products, but maintenance of existing assets constantly increases with any new addition and takes more and more time. It is not just about the technical level. When we start working on any new initiative, we are committed to supporting it in the long term, which means making periodic improvements and modifications while coordinating with stakeholders.   This signals to me that as new features are built, costs are expected to rise correspondingly.  I’d like to understand why that is.  Are these simply feature requests upon existing capabilities or is there some type of recurring ETL work.  I’d like some confidence that tasks are automated correctly and this project can be efficiently maintained.

content.content: I’m a little confused as to whether this team’s mission is more to support other core units or service the general public. I suppose it could be both.  It’s both. We believe it’s equally important to empower other CUs and the whole community. The more good data is available the bigger transparency and safety of the protocol.  would you be able to share your AWS and snowflake usage statistics and expenses?  We will try to prepare and share some data beginning next week.  This signals to me that as new features are built, costs are expected to rise correspondingly. I’d like to understand why that is. Are these simply feature requests upon existing capabilities or is there some type of recurring ETL work. I’d like some confidence that tasks are automated correctly and this project can be efficiently maintained.  For every new feature / dataset there are some additional costs of:  infrastructure (database storage and computing, ETL processes, API endpoints) monitoring (health checks, data quality assurance, workarounds, fixes) maintenance (constant changes in protocol, other protocols, new requirements, optimisation) support (answering questions, problems solving, helping with ad hoc queries)
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: Thanks for your response!  Would it be accurate to say the focus so far has been more on supporting other CUs and as a byproduct, what’s created becomes available for the community or has there been equal time and thought given to what specifically would be useful to be made public?  I’m not saying what’s better, just trying to understand what will be driving the roadmap. In regards to maintenance, all these costs are understandable.  Thank you for breaking them down.  It might be good in the future to also break down exactly how much time is going toward maintenance and how much toward new features.  There’s not much you can do about things like protocol changes but I guess the hope would be that as time goes on, those monitoring, maintenance, and support costs would decrease for fully implemented features that have become more solidified and documented.  Not as much worried about infrastructure costs, more so anything that takes up time.

content.content: During this governance cycle we have had insightful conversations with some of the delegates and we sincerely appreciate their time and feedback. We all agree that the facilitator’s duties require a full time commitment. I’m going to voluntarily resign from this role at the end of April and we will submit a MIP to onboard @tadeo as a new Facilitator. I will stay in the team on a part-time advisory role. By design, the previous budget was focused on servicing a limited number of Core Units to validate the value that a data specific team can provide for the DAO. We know we failed to engage with the wider community outside of those Core Units. Moving forward we will actively communicate updates on our planned activities and ongoing work, and also present the products services and tools in an approachable way to the entire community. The first example could be the public listings in the Snowflake Marketplace (Maker Protocol Parameters and Maker Vaults History), that we finalised last Friday and which we are going to announce to the community next week.  image1920×1219 126 KB
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal
